awd_titl_txt: NRI: FND: COLLAB: Intuitive, Wearable Haptic Devices for Communication with Ubiquitous Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Robotics Initiative (NRI) project will promote the progress of science and beneficially impact human health and quality of life by developing wearable soft robotic devices with distributed tactile stimulation that enable new forms of communication. Human-robot interactions will be commonplace in the near future.  In applications such as self-driving cars and physically assistive devices, interaction will require effective and intuitive bidirectional communication.  Transferring information through vision and sound can be slow and inappropriate in many circumstances.  This project focuses on haptic (touch-based) robotics to enable communication in a salient but private manner that alleviates demands on other sensory channels. This project serves the national interest by advancing knowledge in the fields of human perception, psychology and neuroscience, while developing novel, convergent technology that integrates concepts across the fields of robotics, haptics, and control engineering. Project results will be disseminated through tactile haptic devices for education and publicly available software and data. The project aims to broaden participation of underrepresented groups in engineering through outreach programs, public lab tours, and the mentoring of female and minority graduate students, undergraduates, and high school students.

Wearable haptic systems have the potential to enable private, salient communication between humans and intelligent systems through an underutilized sensory channel (somatosensation). In this research, information will be transmitted through the haptic channel via wearable, ubiquitous, soft robotic devices that provide both passive and active touch interactions with the human user. This research is comprised of four main objectives. First, a characterization of human perception of the forearm will set the requirements for the frequency, amplitude, directions, spacing, and temporal actuation patterns for a two-dimensional array of haptic stimulators that are able to convey a range of haptic cues. Second, the project will develop a wearable, soft, haptic device able to stimulate the skin of one forearm, while also providing mechanical stimuli that are intended to be explored by the fingertips of the other hand. Third, the project will develop rendering algorithms for the haptic device that take into consideration human perceptual abilities for passive stimulation of the arm and active exploration by the fingertips. Fourth, the project team will create application scenarios to evaluate and refine the system. Wearable haptic systems have potential to improve human health and well-being through a variety of applications including: physical cueing for rehabilitation/movement therapy; explosive ordnance defusing; feedback from assistive devices including mobile robots in the home; tactile communication to enable design and e-commerce; immersion in virtual worlds for education; and the facilitation of remote interaction between people.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

In this research, we created systems that allow information tp be transmitted through the haptic channel via wearable, ubiquitous, soft robotic devices that provide both passive and active touch interactions with the human user. This research had four main objectives. First, a characterization of human perception of the forearm was used to set the requirements for the parameters of haptic stimulators that are able to convey a range of haptic cues. Second, the project developed a wearable haptic device that stimulates the skin of one forearm, while also providing mechanical stimuli to be explored by the fingertips of the other hand, as well as novel soft devices for the wrist. Third, the project developed rendering algorithms for the haptic device that take into consideration human perceptual abilities for passive stimulation of the arm and active exploration by the fingertips. Fourth, the project team created application scenarios that were used to evaluate and refine the systems.

Wearable haptic systems have potential to improve human health and well-being through a variety of applications, including physical cueing for rehabilitation/movement therapy; explosive ordnance defusing; feedback from assistive devices including mobile robots in the home; tactile communication to enable design and e-commerce; immersion in virtual worlds for education; and the facilitation of remote interaction between people. This work is the result of a collaboration between faculty and students at Stanford University and Rice University.

Intellectual Merit: This project created new forms of haptic communication that increased the capabilities of wearable devices that could be used to impact human health and quality of life. The increased understanding of human perception, in particular mappings between motion at the fingertips and haptic feedback at the wrist, advanced knowledge in psychology and neuroscience. The haptic device development, in particular 3D-printed soft haptic devices, provided new techniques for robotics and haptics by integrating discoveries across different fields of engineering. 

Broader Impacts: This project could impact human health and quality of life through (1) information transfer between the human and a collaborative robot, (2) movement guidance, and (3) communication between people. The results were disseminated through demonstrations of educational applications, development of tactile haptic devices for education, and software and data made publicly available. Outreach programs, public lab tours, and mentoring of female and minority graduate students, undergraduates, and high school students broadened participation of underrepresented groups in engineering.

    Mine Sarac

  • A new wearable haptic device uses soft pneumatic actuators to provide normal and shear force to the skin of the forearm. A rigid housing and gear motor control the direction of the shear forces. Force/torque, distance, and pressure sensors quantify how the tactor interacts with the skin.
    Kyle Yoshida

    Sophia Williams

    Wearable Haptic Devices Provide Stimulation to the Forearm and the Fingertips
  • We developed an app and case for a smartphone to determine how vibration perception changes with different levels of cognitive (shape-recall task or no task) and physical (walking or sitting) activity. Participants� responses to vibration cues were used to calculate perception thresholds.
    Kyle Yoshida and Joel Kiernan
    Copyrighted
